thread.title: Explained: How Tiahleigh's death is changing the child protection system
thread.title_full: Explained: How Tiahleigh's death is changing the child protection system

author: Chris O'Brien
title: Explained: How Tiahleigh's death is changing the child protection system
text:
The supplementary review contains 17 further recommendations which have been accepted by the Government. 
Among the changes, a central register of home-based childcare services will be created. 
Blue Card authorities will also be provided criminal histories of applicants, and the police commissioner will be allowed to share information about suspects in child safety cases. 
The Government will spend $6 million to upgrade IT systems for faster information sharing between agencies for missing children. 
"We must never stop looking for ways to ensure the safety of Queensland children, especially those who are most vulnerable and at risk," Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said. 
However, Opposition Leader Tim Nicholls has called on the Government to take more immediate action. 
"An IT system isn't going to fix the problem of child deaths in Queensland," he said. What has also been released today? 
Two other reports that looked into the deaths of Queensland children also came out. 
One found 390 children died during 2015-16, with disease and medical conditions the leading cause of death. Forty-six of the deceased were known to the child protection system. 
The other annual report was on child death case reviews. What is still to come? Photo: 21-month-old Mason Jet Lee was found dead by paramedics on June 11, 2016. (Facebook: Emmy Louise) 
There are still several reviews to be handed down. 
The QFCC is reviewing the death of Mason Jet Lee, a toddler who suffered fatal injuries and was found at his Caboolture home last year. Five people have been charged over the death. 
KPMG and a former director-general, Linda Apelt, are reviewing Queensland's child safety procedures and practices. 
Meanwhile, an expert panel including Bravehearts founder Hetty Johnson and Foster Care Queensland CEO Bryan Smith is examining the state's Blue Card and foster care systems. 
Another review will look at operations conducted by the QFCC's Suspected Child Abuse and Neglect Team.
